Hey Bryan,

Thanks for the response.  Before I go, some background information:
The NEAT implementation that I'm using is a pretty heavily modified
version of M. Buckland's Win NEAT.  I've already successfully
performed XOR and several other tests that actually relate to my
project (cat and mouse).

The penalizing _any_ species is what Ken does in his code, so that is
certainly a feasible option.  Following him I've used generations with
no improvement as a measure, but I would be skeptical of using average
fitness as a measure in any task more daunting than XOR.  Personally,
I find that the average fitness of a species can swing considerably
from generation to generation and does not always go up even when on
its way to a solution.

So obviously allowing any species to be sterilized, using my current
criteria, is an option as well as is sterilizing the poorest
performing species based upon it's _age_ being over N generations. 
There is _certainly_ no shortage of options, but I do feel that I'm
basically just throwing darts at a board deciding what to try next and
each "attempt" takes me a day or so to fully test out.

That's brutal.

Mike

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Bryan Adams <bpadams@m...> wrote:
> I recently re-implemented NEAT and verified it on the XOR benchmark.  I 
> haven't re-created the DPNV experiments (I'm doing other things), so 
> take this with a grain of salt ...
> 
> My code penalizes _any_ species that does not achieve a new high in 
> average fitness after N+5 generations (i.e., not just the bottom 2).  I 
> did not see a performance improvement with "delta coding" 
> (redistributing the population to only the top two species), so I left 
> it out.
> 
> [Aside: This policy created the opposite of your problem -- the 
> population would sometimes lose the best individual(s) when the 
> highest-performing species would stagnate and be thusly penalized.  I 
> have been experimenting with providing a reward, either immunity from 
> the age penalty or bonus offspring, to either the species with the 
> highest average fitness or the species containing the population 
> superstar (or some combination of those things).  As is sometimes the 
> case with NEAT, none of these methods proved universally superior, so I 
> just parameterized the various options ...]
> 
> One piece of general advice that I'll offer is that I find that many 
> aspects of the NEAT algorithm can be application specific; what's sauce 
> for XOR is not necessarily sauce for your problem.  I've been using
NEAT 
> to create robot controllers, and I've made a variety of tweaks and 
> additions to the algorithm/parameters and had some success.  The best 
> advice I can give you is to keep detailed records of your algorithmic 
> changes and parameter values when you run experiments so that you don't 
> waste a lot of time trying to figure out how you got a given set of
results.
> 
> And go easy on the brick wall with your coconut.
> 
> --Bryan
> 
> 
> gerbopel wrote:
> > 
> >>On discussing culling species after N generations of
> >>no improvement.
> > 
> > 
> > Okay, now I'm thoroughly confused.  After re-reading over the NEAT
> > material I have and checking K.S.'s source code again, nothing seems
> > to match up.
> > 
> > Specifically the publications state that the lowest performing species
> > over N generations in age will not be reproduced.  However the code
> > uses the any species that has not improved in N generations.
> > 
> > Additionally, there is written: "In rare cases when the fitness of the
> > entire population does not improve for more than 20 generations, only
> > the top two species are allowed to reproduce, refocusing the search
> > into the most promising spaces".  That is from "Evolving NN through
> > Augmenting Topologies".  In code K.S. simply checks to see if the
> > whole population hasn't improved in N+5 generations and then takes
> > only allows to reproduce the top 2 species.
> > 
> > So many different things are being said and being done here, I'm not
> > sure who to listen to.  At the moment I am not allowing the 2 worst
> > species to reproduce if they haven't improved in N generations.  As
> > well, if the whole population has not improved in N+5 generations then
> > I only allow the top 2 species to reproduce.
> > 
> > Unfortunately this is still leading to serious stagnation towards
> > local minima.
> > 
> > Any suggestions would be greatly appreciated as I'm getting to the
> > point of hitting my head on the brick wall here.
> > 
> > Cheers,
